Comment: Winning a game always feels wonderful and it is something that fuels the desire for many people to play more chess, but it is the difficult study and struggle that helps you improve your game. I played this game after a week study of positional play. I undertook it in hopes of improving my ability to place my pieces more aggressively and securely. This game was the reward that I claimed from it.
The game began with an Indian Defense response from my opponent.
The game began with an Indian Defense response from my opponent.
The game began with an Indian Defense response from my opponent.
Here I developed my K-side Knight first, to wait and see where my opponent would place his K-side bishop...
but he develops his other Knight instead, thus transposing into the Mexican defense
I wanted to avoid a pin on my Knight, so I moved the pawn to a3 before developing the Knight to c3.

My opponent responded in similar prophylactics, but this weakens the Black K-side. Furthermore, the pin would hardly have been that annoying for Black, since now, that i played a3, the only good way to develop his K-side bishop to is e7 - and that intercepts the pin, rendering it harmless. Therefore, imho, this was a wasted flank move that also weakened Black K-side.
I continued with my intended development, here expecting my opponent to make the move d5 battling for the CENTRAL CONTROL, creating a position somewhat similar to a Queen Gambit declined...
But my opponent neglected the importance of the center of the board and that allowed me to seize it myself...

With my Q-side Knight developed and not pinned by anything I brought the third pawn into the center of the board.
I can mention, that my previous study had helped me to reevaluate the IMPORTANCE OF THE CENTER myself. Prior to that my view towards the center was somewhat ignorant, even though not entirely non-existent.
My opponent formed a defensive center that allowed me to plan and initiate central breaks, thus giving me a lot of INITIATIVE.

Before planning any sort of an opening in the center I need to get my own King off of it. I intend to castle K-side, so I need to develop my K-side Bishop first. Developing it to e2 would be completely passive ...the Bishop does a whole lot more on d3, most importantly it plans the move e5, attacking the Knight and opening up the b1-h7 diagonal, that becomes very strong if Black castles K-side.
My opponent might be intending a flank attack with b5, but it doesn't carry much threat as b5 would be responded with b3 - securing the center one more time. So a6 was also a wasted move...
I BRING MY KING TO SAFETY
My opponent castles K-side and my e5 break is claiming more value

I make my last preparation with 9. Re1 - it gives me more attacking lines against the Black King. Here I might be thinking about exchanging my f3 Knight to open up the d1-h5 diagonal for my queen and then plan for some sacrificial attacks like Bxh6. It also enables me with a possible Rook lift to the third rank and increase the pressure on the pawns in front of the Black King. Additionally, it increases my control of the e pawn. Other than all that, it is a normal developing move that masks up my pending plan a little...
My opponent makes yet another passive move. It might have been much better to fianchetto that Bishop...

Now my e5 plan comes into action. It will force the Black Knight to move, thus giving me a tempo while i succeed in clearing the b1-h7 diagonal. Moreover, the Black pieces are denied access to the K-side, making my K-side sacrifices worth thinking about.
Now White is threatening to take the h7 Knight without any compensation for Black
g6 would loose to Bxh6, so Ng5 is the only valid response for Black.
